AMGeO now provides a new api object for interacting with AMGeO in a pythonic and
notebook-friendly manner
class, you will need to create a new instance of it
Create a new instance of the `AMGeOApi` class!
When running AMGeO, a local file system directory will be selected to store your assimilative maps. By default, AMGeo will use
But, if you want to specify another directory, you can set this in the API instance using
. This can be either a relative or absolute path.
To generate assimilative maps, you will have to load specific settings from AMGeO. Conveniently, AMGeO’s new API allows for a simple way to load AMGeO’s default settings using a
Call the `AMGeOApi` method `get_controller` to get a new controller instance.

. This method takes both a hemisphere and a date argument. For example, if we wanted to generate maps for dates:
and on the Northern hemisphere, we can call
# datetime module is used for passing dates/datetimes
# generate maps for a given hemisphere
Once complete, we will be able to see generated AMGeO maps for each datetime.
supports multiple different ways of generating maps based on dates/datetimes
Will generate data for a specific date and time

Will generate data for 5 min slices over the entire date provided
Ex: date(2013, 5, 5) => datetime(2013, 5, 5, 0, 2, 30), datetime(2013, 5, 5, 0, 7, 30), …
This will handle each element within the list on a case by case basis, in a bulk job
Once we have generated AMGeO maps, we might be interested in browsing what maps we have available.
method that can be used in two ways.
Browse based on a hemisphere which dates have AMGeO maps already generated.
Specify a date and hemisphere for specific times that AMGeO has generated maps for
Browse AMGeO data for the date 1-2-2016 on the southern hemisphere
The last and most important piece of AMGeO’s new API is the ability to load AMGeO maps into
, with no work needed other than calling
, to allow for you load various dates/datetimes on a given hemisphere into one dataset.

Will load all maps availabe from a date

you can load from multiple dates into one dataset

frontmatter.title: Module 4: Intro to AMGeO
frontmatter.description: In this module, you will get an intro to AMGeO and  learn how to use AMGeOs API in Jupyter Notebook
